Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigation of second language lexical representation and processing of Mandarin tones

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the national language of the People's Republic of China, Mandarin Chinese has obvious importance in the modern world. Progress in our understanding of how Mandarin can be learned more effectively is thus of national interest for the United States. Mandarin is a lexical tone language, where pitch cues on syllables distinguish words. Learning lexical tones is known to be difficult for native speakers of English, however, the nature of the difficulty and its causes are not well understood beyond the earliest stages of learning. This project will address two main questions: First, what are adult second language learners' mental representations of Mandarin tone categories like? Second, what is the nature of the difficulty learners have during real-time word recognition?

A first set of experiments will use behavioral measures of accuracy and response time to make inferences about the quality of listeners' mental representations for a specific Mandarin tone (Tone 3) and its variants (allotones). If learners' responses are less accurate or slower for one variant of Tone 3, this may indicate a bias in their perception, potentially due to common teaching practices that emphasize only one form of Tone 3. A second set of experiments will examine event-related potentials (ERPs) and behavioral decisions in response to spoken Mandarin words. Specifically, research will examine the N400 response to words and nonwords and compare it to the behavioral decisions that follow. While previous behavioral research suggests learners have severely decreased sensitivity to tones in disyllabic words, this new research will provide real-time evidence of learners' responses to tones, potentially revealing sensitivity that is not captured in behavioral decisions. Results will contribute to our understanding of the acquisition of lexical tones by adult second language learners and may lead to improvements in learning and teaching of Mandarin and other tone languages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the national language of the People's Republic of China, Mandarin has obvious importance in the modern world. Progress in our understanding of how Mandarin can be learned more effectively is thus of national interest for the United States. Mandarin is a lexical tone language, this means that pitch changes on syllables distinguish words. Learning lexical tones is known to be difficult for native speakers of English, however, the nature of the difficulty and its causes are not well understood beyond the earliest stages of learning. This project addressed two main questions: First, what are adult second language learners' mental representations of Mandarin tone categories like? Second, what is the nature of the difficulty that advanced adult second language learners have during real-time word recognition?

A first set of experiments tested how well native Chinese and second language learners could identify the four Mandarin tones. On the basis of their response patterns, we made inferences about the quality of their mental representations for one specific Mandarin tone (the low Tone 3). The phonetic qualities of Tone 3 change depending on whether it is produced in isolation or in context, presenting a complicated set of patterns for second language speakers to learn. We examined how accurately people could identify Mandarin tones in isolated syllables or in context. Compared to the other three Mandarin tones, native Chinese speakers were less accurate for Tone 3 in isolation, but improved in accuracy for Tone 3 in context. In contrast, second language speakers were less accurate at identifying Tone 3 both in isolation and in context. This may indicate that the second language learners' mental representations for Tone 3 do not reflect the full variety with which Tone 3 actually occurs, and might be due to common teaching practices that emphasize only the isolated form of Tone 3. Thus, one practical implication of our results is that teachers should focus more on the contextual form of Tone 3. We conducted a follow-up experiment exploring these issues using web-based experimental platforms. Results of the full set of experiments are being analyzed and will be submitted for publication in the near future.

A second set of experiments examined people's neural responses (event-related potentials) and behavioral decisions in response to spoken Mandarin words. These experiments tested people's abilities to recognize familiar words and reject similar sounding fake words. The fake words differed from real words in a single vowel (fake vowel words) or a single tone (fake tone words). We found that second language learners had more difficulty rejecting the fake tone words than the fake vowel words. Their behavioral decisions were reflected in relatively weaker neural responses (N400s) to fake tone words compared to fake vowel words. A vocabulary and tone knowledge test revealed that second language learners often did not know or were incorrect about the tones that belong to Mandarin words, even when they knew the meanings of those words, and often even though they were confident that they knew the tones.

Together, these experiments have increased our understanding of the long-term learning challenges associated with lexical tones in adult second language acquisition. Results indicate that challenges persist in every aspect of tone learning, including hearing tones accurately, recognizing the tones in spoken words, and remembering the tones that belong to words. Our results have contributed to theories of second language acquisition by showing similarities and differences in the acquisition of tones compared to other speech sounds. Practically speaking, our study suggests teachers should seek ways to help learners remember tones more accurately and to retain that knowledge. Additionally, rather than focusing on tones in isolation, teachers should help learners use tones actively while listening to meaningful speech.

A published report of some of these results is available in the journal Studies in Second Language Acquisition. Results have also been shared at professional conferences, as well as in presentations to Chinese language teachers and second language learners.
